snippet: A neighborhood in the tourist district of the capital, Ankara, has become a hub for wooing new members of the Islamic State, even as the group holds Turkish hostages.
abstract: Turkey, NATO member with undercurrent of Islamist discontent, is one of biggest sources of recruits to Islamic State in Iraq and Syria; recruits cite group's ideological appeal to disaffected youths as well as the money it pays fighters from its flush coffers; as many as 1,000 Turks have joined ISIS, and CIA estimates that group has from 20,000 to 31,500 fighters in Iraq and Syria.
lead_paragraph: A neighborhood in the tourist district of the capital, Ankara, has become a hub for wooing new members of the Islamic State, even as the group holds Turkish hostages.

headline.main: ISIS Draws a Steady Stream of Recruits From Turkey
headline.print_headline: From Turkey, ISIS Draws Steady Stream of Recruits

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations
